Today‚Äôs hearing is about two new rules the Department of Health and Human Services has proposed to implement this provision in the 21st Century Cures Act.
These hearings led to a bipartisan group of HELP Committee members working together to include a provision in the 21st Century Cures Act to stop information blocking and encourage interoperability.
So, in 2015, this committee held six bipartisan hearings and formed a working group to find ways to fix the interoperability of electronic health records.

A major reason for that is that the records are not interoperable. Interoperability is when electronic health records are able to talk to one another and seamless send information between doctors and hospitals.

In 2015, while this Committee worked on the 21st Century Cures Act, we realized that, in many cases, electronic health records added to administrative burden and increased unnecessary health care spending.

I call on every member of the United States Senate to put their political self-interests aside and do the right thing for people who are really suffering right now. Time is of essence, and people back home are counting on us to get this done. #DisasterRelief
Every day we continue debating this issue is a day that people across the country face crippling uncertainty.

This bipartisan disaster relief package is a win for our farmers, it's a win for families and businesses who were devastated by historic hurricanes in the Southeast and wildfires in the West, and it's a win for the people in Puerto Rico who the President has previously helped.

Some senators argue we should allocate more funding for Puerto Rico.
 
I would remind them this is the same level of funding they have previously supported.

To ensure Puerto Rico continues to have the resources it needs to recover from Hurricane Maria and Hurricane Irma, our disaster relief bill includes $600 million in additional nutrition assistance for the most vulnerable families in Puerto Rico.

Our bill includes $3 billion for agriculture disaster relief and additional funds for Georgia and other states like Florida, Alabama, the Carolinas, Alaska, Hawaii, California, Iowa, Nebraska, Missouri, and Kansas  that have battled natural disasters over the last year.
.@SenatorIsakson & I, along with several other senators, have introduced a stand-alone supplemental disaster relief bill. It‚Äôs being considered on the floor of the Senate this week.
And, yes, our farmers are praying for other people around the country who have been devastated just like they have.

Every night, farmers in Georgia get on their knees and pray help will soon come. 

They pray their lenders will show compassion.

They pray they won‚Äôt go bankrupt.

They pray they will be able to provide for their families.
If we don‚Äôt help our farmers right now, they may lose their businesses and their livelihoods through no fault of their own. That‚Äôs the reality we‚Äôre facing here.
It‚Äôs unacceptable that Washington‚Äôs intransigence continues to threaten the livelihoods of the very people who sent us here to represent them.

Disaster aid should have been funded as soon as we had an estimate of the damage, which was just a few weeks after the hurricane hit. Instead, disaster aid got caught up in a partisan spending battle, and in typical Washington fashion, Congress kicked the can down the road.
It‚Äôs been 5 months since Hurricane Michael ravaged the Southeast, and Congress has done nothing to help people who are barely hanging on right now. That‚Äôs shameful. (THREAD)
